etymologies: early 18th century. Partly from an unattested Southern New England Algonquian cognate of the forms listed below

definitions: Usually in form wickup. More fully "wickup tree". The American basswood, Tilia americana, which has fibrous inner bark used to make rope, bags, etc.
Usually in form wicopy. The eastern leatherwood, Dirca palustris, which has tough, pliable bark used to make rope, cord, etc.
More fully "wickup plant". Rosebay willowherb or fireweed, Chamaenerion angustifolium.

notes.text: Now only in lists of alternative names for this plant.
